job_title: Technical Support Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: The campus is beautiful, with lots of restaurants in the area.
cons: There is a horrific disregard for Booth employees. Regularly violates Americans with Disabilities Act provisions. HR was absolutely useless in mediating issues related to poor management. Exploits vulnerable employees--at that point in my career I was not good at advocating for myself or standing up to abusive colleagues, and so I was bullied into accepting extra "grunt work", even in my off hours. Management was abusive, and colleagues used that as their model. Any suggestions I made were treated in one of two ways: either they were mocked and discarded, or accepted and the credit for the idea stolen by others. I consider the 3 years I spent here as the absolute nadir of my career trajectory, and I would advise anyone considering a position here to flee the vicinity and never look back.

pros: Great benefits (easy to see them as well by just searching "uchicago employee benefits" and no log in needed to see everything), was able to occasionally work from home pre-covid and am now fully remote, can set my own schedule so long as I work the number of hours I'm supposed to in a week. Overall a pretty low stress job, but my role is very specific and a research assistant position is really going to be shaped by the lab it is in.
cons: Pay for research assistants is based on whatever was stipulated in the grant for the research project(s), so you can't really negotiate. Only given about a 2% raise each year for "cost of living" which barely does anything, and for the financial year of 2020-21 they cancelled that raise along with retirement contributions (supposedly set to come back on July 1 of 2021) due to covid. Also, it is a big university and has many issues that any academic setting may have, such as extreme employee bloat, lack of communication between offices and departments, weird academic hierarchies, etc.

review_title: Working as staff at a University is not easy
pros:
Flexibility - work/life balance
Nice people (staff and some faculty)
Potentially the opportunity to grow intellectually (but not so easy, depending on work schedule)
Ability to use the library, which is incredible in terms of book availability
Some tuition support (although not 100%)
cons: Being in a staff role at a university is very hard.  Faculty simply do not respect you.  Faculty generally think they are the smartest people in the room and they feel anyone without a PhD is not that smart.  They also do not understand that a staff person has a career.  There is little feedback/review.  There is no easy way to know of other opportunities on campus.  And since funding is ALWAYS an issue at a university, there are little or no funds for staff employees related to career growth (e.g. training, ability to attend conferences etc.)  Administration (whatever that means beyond deans) do a really poor job of interacting with staff.  (They don't do that much with students either but really nothing with staff.) If you have motivation and drive but are not faculty, a university, especially the University of Chicago, is probably not the best place for you, especially long term.  It could be a good person for a short term opportunity

review_title: Positive experience at the Department of Psychology Laboratory
pros: Though the flexibility you are given completely depends on the size of the lab and the personality of the PI, generally I found the environment to be incredibly encouraging of personal development.  The professors inspire respect from the research assistants.  Everyone is held to a high standard for hard work, intelligence, and academic rigor.  The social environment is congenial and family-like.  We celebrated everyone's accomplishments, big or small.  I was allowed to attend HR workshops to enhance my skills.
cons: The general mood at UChicago is somber and highly scholarly.  It is not a place that is encouraging of frivolous, non-academic pursuits.  While it is a great place to work for anyone who wants research experience, or an insider view into professorial or doctoral student life, I don't think it would be a very relevant or "useful" place to work for those not interested in entering some serious academically oriented research.  The hierarchy within the labs are also quite rigid, as years of experience, and educational level pre-determine your level of position within the laboratory.  You would have to be seriously proactive and have great insights in order to be allowed to pursue your own project.  The opportunity is open to do so, but you really would have to be quite persistent and be able to navigate funding issues.

review_title: The best place to be a student ever.
pros: Hyde Park is awesome, it's just far enough from Downtown that you feel like you're in a small neighborhood. The bike paths along the lake are great to ride on. U of C is a place like no other. There are always interesting events and lectures to go to. Campus is easily walkable and there's lots of on and off campus housing available, as well as good public transportation to and from campus from all parts of the city. If you like academia and want to work at a top university, this place would be a great fit for you.
cons: Don't work here if you're not into the academic way of life. There aren't a lot of good places to eat directly on campus, although I would recommend Cobb coffee shop for its atmosphere, but just down 57th street there are a ton of places, and if you like Thai food, definitely order some from the Snail. I really don't have much to complain about - I worked designing and machining experimental equipment in a physics lab and found it extremely rewarding. I don't know what any of the other divisions were like, but my experience with the Physics department was pretty much all positive.

review_title: I worked for the Math Department at the University of Chicago as a Teacher's Assistant
pros: Overall, if you enjoy math and teaching, this is a good way to get your feet wet in some sort of teaching position. The Professors for your class are usually nice and willing to give advice as to how to run your TA sessions.
cons:
Because you are teaching a core class required by the University, most of the kids don't want to be there. While many of the kids just want to make it through the class, you have to deal with the occasional complete lack of interest or blatant academic dishonesty.

The solution manual is available online, and it has some mistakes in it. Given how unique these mistakes are (they tend to be typos), it becomes obvious that many of the kids cheat. This presents a bit of an awkward situation, and while I chose to ignore it, presenting it to the students or professor could lead to some undesirable situations.

Finally, the hourly wage of 8.50 an hour is a bit low.

review_title: Interesting place to work but has it's challenges
pros:
The Lab is doing cutting edge research and provided great hands-on experience in experimental research design for an aspiring researcher. I had a lot of autonomy to problem solve. During times when the lab was not busy, I had the opportunity to pursue research ideas and create new projects. I had exposure to just about every aspect of research operations so I left feeling very equipped for my next career steps in academic research. 

Although I was able to learn a lot, the challenges of the job could outweigh the positives, depending what a person wants to get out of the position (see cons).  I cautioned the person who came after me before they accepted the job to know what they were getting into. My advice is go in eyes wide open.
cons: The Lab's leaders are busy with other responsibilities so there were often delays in communication and decision-making. Sometimes the leaders forgot the decisions they had made in the past, requiring that we rehash discussions we'd had weeks or months before. At times those rehashed discussions led to new decisions, requiring a change of direction and the feeling that time was wasted and work was not appreciated or valued. This was especially stressful when we were working under tight deadlines.

pros: Stable position, firing an employee is not easy
cons: No growth, hierarchy, micro management

review_title: UChicago Doesn't Care About its Employees
pros:
-Flexible, many people leave early or come in late
-Good benefits
cons:
-University of Chicago doesn't promote people. You have to find a new job at the university above you and apply to it. People who barely come to work and do nothing at their desks are treated the same as people who work 12 hour days and add measurable value to the office. 
-You also can't get raises, unless you're already a top level manager. The most you can hope for is 2-3% a year, regardless of how well you've done.
-The University always talks about how employee retention is important, but doesn't offer any incentives to stay. Those who do stay are people who aren't good enough to get jobs elsewhere, so management suffers. 
-The offices are restructured at least once every two years, so the job you were hired for may no longer exist. 
-You're either expected to do virtually no work or pick up the slack for those who do no work. It's all or nothing here. 
-Goals and strategies are not set by higher management, making it hard to know what exactly you're supposed to be doing. 
-These are all problems stemming from the top, that are unlikely to change.

pros: Great pedigree in educating the next generation
cons: Lost mission in educating the next generation

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Chicago, IL
pros: benefits, 9-5, good coworkers, close to home
cons: poor management. Understaffed over worked and underpaid. sometimes you can’t take a lunch

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: UofC is a big place.  There may be pockets where you can find a decent low-level job.
cons:
UofC is an institution that is perpetually under-staffed, with departments woefully underfunded.  This results in a lot of unrealistic expectations on management.  Those managers - particularly the good ones - don't stick around long, as they find better jobs downtown or at better run higher-ed institutions.  And therefore most departments are poorly managed.

In the mean time, lower-level employees are rarely supported due to forever-changing management.  And so employee development, promotions, and pay increases are very rare. 

If you're at Chicago and like it, by all means stay.  If you're a recent grad, Chicago might give you your first "real" job.  From my personal experience and the experience of my UChicago peers, taking a staff position at UofC is always a mistake.  Never, ever leave a pretty decent job for UofC.

pros:
As a BSD graduate student, there are a lot of perks, but few are unique the University of Chicago. It's mid-tier research university with some very strong programs and some weak. The quality of your time here is largely determined by your personal investment and your advisor... choose wisely.

The BSD had put a respectable amount of effort in career guidance for graduate students. Keep in mind that the number of biology PhDs that make it to professorships are single digit percentages, so statistically, you will be doing something outside academia.
cons:
Bloated administration.
Far from Chicago's north-side cultural attractions.
Obscene spending on fancy buildings, landscaping.
TAship pay for the BSD is only $1200 per class. Basically not worth the additional effort, and extra teaching is discouraged (even though a majority of future faculty positions are primarily teaching).
The health insurance isn't great. Unexpected medical complications can cost thousands out of pocket, which is hard on a 30k stipend.

pros: Benefits, hours, time off, vacation, students
cons: Your creative collaboration will not be tolerated

pros: Good work life balance and creative people that are interesting to talk to and learn from both in and out of work.
cons: As a contractor: Treated as an outsider, no training provided other than read the outdated handbook. Employees were bullied and scared of management and don't express opinions or ideas.  Departmental information such as projects and priorities were never provided even when asked. Employees would be singled out and dismissed or excluded from departmental meetings because of personal differences with the person running those meetings. Was told by one employee "Don't question any process or procedures, don't stand out in any way, keep your head down and do your job". Unless you're an insider who went to school and moved into the department you'll have a difficult time being accepted.

review_title: Chapin Hall: Warm, if not a little sedate, research community
pros: Lots of little employee perks- like Thursday Happy Hour, health contests, free starbucks coffee, lots of provided meals, great office resources and research access. Bu the best part was the high quality research and policy professionals. They are often working on great projects and for the most part they are willing to help junior faculty. Plus with great tech and support staff,  overall it is a welcoming and academically stimulating environment.
cons:
The organization was going through transition when I left and many people were laid off and some of the most well funded researchers left.  They are no longer affiliated with the University of Chicago, which may impact resources and research access. 

Also, I was really strung along. They promised me that they would hire me full time and provide me with health insurance within a few months, but kept pushing it back due to funding problems.

pros: Beautiful campus, with wonderful new buildings. Nice colleagues that want to do good work.
cons: Inadequate investment in the operation.  Poor budget design makes meaningful institutional improvements impossible.

review_title: Independence, high quality research facilities, the pace of work is slow
job_title: Director's Postdoctoral Fellow in Lemont, IL
pros: Excellent compensation and benefits package as compared to similar organizations. The advantage of living in a suburb near Chicago. High quality life. Excellent research facilities and people are generally very helpful towards post-docs. Overall a good place to make a lifelong career if you can find a permanent position.
cons: Pace of work is slow mainly because of the amount of paperwork involved. No clear guidance on transition to a permanent position. Many times you have to generate your own work otherwise you can be here for two years and have nothing to show for it.

pros:
-- Name recognition.
-- Attractive benefits. Curiously, many new hires soon choose to have a baby.
-- Easy to coast, once found your "spot". Unsurprisingly, many (not only veterans) are patiently on-track till retirement.
-- Low but steady [annual] reviews/raises. Yearly percent bonus.
-- Discounted U Chicago tuition (evening classes, of course). Some choose evening MBA or fin-math, if accepted. 
-- Great library, can also use online (journals).
cons:
-- Limited professional growth (at least in IT). The titles are almost made-up and don't come with an implied control share.
-- Largely obsolete technologies. Hiring policies seem to favor non-challenging followers, thus there's a general lack of up-to-date professionals.
-- Stagnant projects and fragmented teams (often a team of one). Project management  is openly incompetent.
-- Stale command-and-control culture. Office politics is flourishing: favoritism, rumors, lack of transparency.
-- General lack of motivation. Senior management is allergic to responsibility, yet repressive of initiative.

review_title: Administration does not care about staff
pros: You're surrounded by really smart people, and the work is often interesting. I've heard the pay and benefits are good compared to other colleges and universities in the area, although lower than comparable salaries in government or the private sector. Some departments have excellent managers and coworkers.
cons: The culture is arrogant and elitist. Many faculty and especially the upper administration demonstrate little to no respect for staff or the surrounding community. Administration makes poor decisions and show a lack of common sense or sound strategy in decision-making. Administration salaries are way too high compared to staff. The President acts more like a CEO than a faculty administrator, and seems to be corporatizing the University. The Hyde Park campus is difficult to commute to unless you live in Hyde Park or nearby. There are no direct CTA trains, the Metra Electric line does not connect to any of the other Metra lines, and parking is extremely difficult. The University has done nothing to alleviate this problem. Even if your department tries to maintain decent work-life balance, the lengthy commute undermines these efforts.

pros: Lots of talented staff who are underpaid but work like they're overpaid.  Most staff are dedicated to the best that the institution offers, and go above and beyond, and many faculty and students are appreciative and supportive of staff work on their behalf.
cons: Humanities HR is unprofessional and at time, abusive.  Higher level administration at the level of the Humanities and the U of C in general is frequently tone deaf to staff issues, and treats staff like naughty children when they have legitimate work concerns. Imagine the worst of corporate business practices without the protections that the business environment has in place to protect its employees.  Staff often take on faculty and high level administrative duties to compensate for incompetent faculty administrators, and without due compensation.

pros: The people I've met here at UChicago have been some of the nicest & most genuine. I've had the pleasure of working with some of the smartest minds in their field.
cons: This was my first job straight out of college, and when I was hired it was explained to me that there wasn't much upward mobility in my current position. Given that I was happy to have a job period, I didn't really think about it at the time. 4+ years later, I wish I could sacrifice some of the benefits that I receive for higher pay & more upward mobility. The 2% increase yearly (because this is technically a not-for-profit institution) does not keep up with the general cost-of-living increases.

review_title: Excellent career building experience but compensation low
job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: Many great ideas from all of the world. Beautiful campus and many cultural activities. Hard workers are recognized and respect is earned fairly. Research is a priority and has near equal footing with education. Employee orientation and HR new hire process is excellent. It is a place to obtain career development skills.
cons: Social classes are highly prevalent. It is fully demonstrated how high level faculty and the rest of the staff are geographically segregated by parking. Constructional feedback is not encouraged. Work load is unfairly distributed and compensation is below average.Many people commute from far places because they cannot afford living close to the campus. The location of the campus is dangerous especially after 7pm.

review_title: Fantastic, UChicago respects you as a person and is very fair
pros:
They pay well compared to other similar jobs for people without degrees
Great variety of jobs to choose from, and it's easy to move departments if you so choose
great campus
many coffee shops nearby
they really respect their employees and try to do what is fair
cons:
it can be stuffy
if you don't agree with your boss, you're in for trouble
very much a shut-up and do your work mentality
very slow with pay raises, in fact you won't get one unless you're about to quit

pros: I have been work at the University of Chicago for two years until last September. UChicago is a great place to work, and my department has a flexible working time, nice working environments. UChicago also provides good benefits to Employee. The boss is super nice and support his employee career development, and colleges are friendly and supportive. Overall, UChicago is an awesome place.
cons: Sometimes you will be asked to do multiple projects at the same time, which will be done by a certain time window. It is a little bit challenge, but worth it in a long run.

pros: The reputation of the University, may be
cons:
1. Too many office politics. For example, around 10 people left the office during 2 years. Most of them left in anger because of the office politics. I was impressed that an employee sent us a resign letter after she left and she locked all boxes before she left without leaving the keys. A funny thing is that 7 financial administrators at Physical Science Division left together. There are some many examples like this. 

2. Lazy team. There are so many lazy and stupid employees working there even though the school has many outstanding professors and students. For example, an administrator can take several month to close an account, not because there are so many accounts or the professor is out, because the administrator is lazy. If you want to learn some useful skills or  continue to improve your career, don't consider this place. 

3. IT system is pretty old. 25 years old grant management system.

pros: Ability to cross-train, develop innovative solutions to difficult problems, and obtain a more holistic experience in your field.  Pay is at or above market for administrative functions.  I was able to work with a few of the most intelligent and collaborative individuals that I have had the pleasure to encounter in my career.
cons: "A culture of heroes" - those who naturally enjoy helping, succeeding and strive for perfection are devoured and eventually drown with the amount of work that finds its way to their desks. Performance management is non-existent so the non-value added employees remain while the high-performers cycle in and subsequently burn out.  Accountability doesn't exist and there is no desire to change this.

review_title: The work environment is nice and ample scope to focus on personal research work.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: The university gives a quarter off (out of 3 quarters) with pay to focus on research. If you're TA in a rich department, you might get graders for grading the homeworks and thus you have less workload.
cons: The medical they offer through United Health insurance is a very shitty one. It's expensive and still not very helpful for poor graduate students. The deductible amount is around $250 and after that it's 10% copay. And as a bonus, we get taxed on the health insurance premium because the students have to pay the entire insurance premium at the beginning of each quarter and the University reimburses the amount through the monthly paychecks.

job_title: Assistant Director of Development in Chicago, IL
pros:
-Staff benefits from having development resources and being able to specialize more in their roles if their team has adequate support centrally. 
-There are training opportunities, and since it's such a big place, you have other opportunities to advance at the same institution.
-The University itself is fantastic - great product for fundraising.
cons:
-Staff below director-level are very underpaid and leadership does not seem to connect this to the major turnover issue. 
-The culture does not encourage entrepreneurship, even if your manager or team supports new ideas. There's no consistency among teams or divisions. Your experience would depend completely upon your individual team.
-The experience is very different for lower-level staff than senior staff.

job_title: Equipment Engineering Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: High funding, smart co-workers. Interesting projects and problems to work on. Access to very high-end equipment.
cons: Leadership is very supportive, but clearly understaffed. One of the three main managers left, at the same time that a third was supposed to be brought on. Basically the whole thing hinges on one guy right now. This should be a temporary issue, but it has effected the experience of working there.

review_title: Worked for a long time but disappointed in the end
job_title: Senior Analyst / Programmer in Chicago, IL
pros:
- Okay salary and benefits.
- Can be very rewarding if you find a good group to support, which I did.
- Good environment for people with scholarly interests, library excellent.
cons:
- Out-of-date enterprise software in IT Services, long overdue for replacement.
- Recently attempts to "change the culture" (much needed) have made things worse instead of better.
- People are put on report for being "disruptive" when they are trying to raise a problem; so the fear of being fired is genuine.
- Reviews were not given consistently in the past. Perhaps this explains some of the problems in starting up after more than a decade without.

review_title: Academic Environments Are Not All That You'd Expect
pros: I was hired into a clerical position as an entry-level (recent grad) employee. There were lots of training opportunities, especially for specific software applications, if you knew which ones to pursue and could make the case for their relevance to your supervisor. Benefits were great and afforded lots of options; leave time was very generous (3 weeks vacation, 5 personal days, 10 sick days, lots of holidays, summer hours).
cons: Mentorship was minimal, and the bureaucracy made moving within the organization difficult.

review_title: Departments are great - central administration varies
pros: Many departments stand by their students at every turn - in math, we get a year's guidance before we teach independently, and I can't name a reasonable request I've made of the department that was denied.
cons: Central administration is... highly politicized/balkanized. Most of the people in it are good, but you're bounced from one person to another when the system's working - and when it's not, you're stuck talking to someone who (even if they seem competent) is probably deceiving you (or themselves) about what they can actually accomplish.

pros: It's a well revered institution in the country and has great pride associated with working here. There are lots of opportunities within the larger campus community for those who would like to switch departments/schools. There's decent work life balance depending on the office you work for (more stressful if working in admissions for example when deadlines have to be met). The school in itself offers great events/programs that staff can attend to learn more about the community and world issues.
cons: It's very competitive to get into and it helps if you network well current employees to get a leg up in the hiring process. It's also very hierarchical, and very top down way of leadership.

pros: The University offers good benefits and a great work atmosphere. Staff members work with internationally-famous faculty. Many staffers and faculty live in Hyde Park, which means your neighbors, coworkers, and friends might very well all be the same people. The intellectual values of the University means that even relatively junior staffers can disagree with higher-ups and have a reasonable discussion about the next course of action.
cons: The pay is low for staff compared to what they would make in the for-profit sector. The University is slow to fill open positions, which makes life difficult for anyone working in an office with a vacancy. There also seems to be an unwritten policy that it's better to use someone up, and let them quit than give them a raise or promotion and have them stay.

review_title: Center for Research in Security Prices. - Enabled bullying
pros: Aside from the cons, the benefits of having this job are it is a very relaxed and un-corporate like environment. Good benefits and flex time.
cons: the Center of Research in Security Prices has a team of 6 analysts, three have been there over four years and get away with doing nothing at work, but get credit for being the most knowledgable. These tenured analysts bully younger analysts and do not provide any training, mentoring, or help on understanding new concepts. Management enables this bullying and shows no support for new analysts when issues are brought up.

review_title: It helps to have an academic background
pros: Fantastic place to work, especially if you are familiar with institutions of higher education and the way they work. You will be surrounded by lots of really smart people who take their work and mission very seriously, and pride themselves on doing/being the best they can.
cons: Everything you do or try takes lots of time and to develop. Every idea and decision is examined, discussed, evaluated, challenged, refined, improved, and discussed again, before moving forward. This is something the University of Chicago particularly prides itself on, and I suspect most of the staff there would consider this a solid endorsement, however in my experience, the end result did not necessarily justify the means.

review_title: Operations and Capital Projects Teams Need Better Leadership!
pros:
Work-Life Balance 
Benefits are good
Near public transportation
cons:
Ethics - Leadership allows unethical behavior from Directors and above and hides their bad behavior
Operations Team is not in alignment with the values of the University
Capital Project Team and Operations are not in alignment
Reports of Discrimination and Retaliation are frequent in these department
Yearly increases are minimal
Extremely political
Safety between campus and Harper Court is concerning.\

review_title: if you like doing one thing indefinitely, this is the place.
pros: Good benefits, reasonable salary, flexible hours, lovely campus in a nice neighborhood, multiple lunch opportunities, relaxed atmosphere, reasonable deadlines, access to a great library collection print and online, seems to keep up-to-date with IT with regards to desktops, network, etc.
cons: No advancement opportunities, poor/nonexistent management or management by inertia, little concern for staff as individuals deserving respect, decentralized management approach across the board does not make sense for everything, some work areas are pristine/new/renovated while others are dirty/old/long overdue for renovation, VERY poor day-to-day maintenance of buildings, runs too many legacy systems which should have been replaced years ago.

pros: If you are someone who enjoys lifelong learning, being at a top research institution is a fantastic experience. There are many free lectures and workshops one can attend. I adore being part of a vibrant community which is present in spades both in the neighborhood (Hyde Park) and at the University. Great, smart colleagues who care equally as much about the mission of the University. Good benefits package.
cons: At least in my area, there are not many opportunities for promotions. I like what I do and have been doing it for many years but, unlike at many businesses, there isn't always an opportunity for promotions and salary negotiations.

review_title: A pleasant place to work if benefits are not a priority
pros: World class university community.  As such, you have exciting opportunities to participate in intellectually stimulating community events.  There are first rate speakers visiting campus with great regularity.  Also, the U of C has an excellent work/life balance.  Smart colleagues.  Nice people.
cons:
The benefits package is pretty terrible, especially in comparison to peer institutions. The tuition reimbursement is embarrassing, actually.  You would think the U of C would have liberal reimbursement policy in order to attract and retain young talent (after all it is an "elite" group working here, right?).  HOwever, they have THE WORST tuition remission of top tier universities.

There is some Harvard envy here.

review_title: Beautiful campus of passive aggressive colleagues
pros: The benefits are excellent and some of the students are some of the most amazing people I've met.
cons: Lack of diversity with high level management and administrator positions. Some employees were favored so they were allowed to bully other employees. Staff members were not informed about how to file grievances nor were town hall meetings planned.

pros: The pay as a (recent) undergraduate is pretty good–grad students is a little higher. A lot of flexibility in terms of hours, both in terms of quantity and in terms of allocation. It probably also depends on your field. Being in the social sciences, I was given a lot of leeway in both of these respects. I can't really speak to full time staff or faculty, but I had a pleasant experience with the University's management. The experience I had really gave me a lot of skills that will help me later on in the job market.
cons: The actual administrative process of getting officially hired was a slow. This could likely be due to HR being understaffed, but I couldn't say with any certainty.

pros: UChicago is a vibrant academic community populated with highly intelligent, dedicated, and motivated staff. The University offers excellent benefits including half price tuition to prestigious degree programs.
cons: The University comprises a vast bureaucracy plagued by outdated systems that do not integrate well. It is often difficult to know what is happening on campus or how to effectively collaborate as a result. Some departments are better funded than others, and numerous new programs and centers are founded as a result of a donor gift, but are not resourced in a sustainable manner. UChicago is a faculty run university, which means that faculty are supported in any endeavor without much strategic vetting, while staff is tasked with carrying out said endeavors, often while underresourced.

review_title: One of the best jobs I've had.
job_title: Senior Writer, Strategy and Communications in Chicago, IL
pros: I loved working with very smart and talented people. We were also empowered to design and deliver high quality creative. Although Chicago is an academic institution, we had very generous budgets, which enabled us to use the best vendors and tools.
cons: The compensation wasn't as high as what I might have earned in the business sector. I was willing to accept that as a trade-off for better work-life balance, but I was shocked to learn that my manager, a senior leader on our team and one of the best creative directors and editors I've worked with in my career, suffered salary compression so severe that she was barely making more that her direct reports. That's not a good way to reward loyalty or performance.

pros: The only reason for the one star is because the benefit plans have lots of options.  Expensive, but lots of options.
cons: Low pay; no respect for staff - for example allowing faculty or other people with no education and experience in my field to second-guess my decisions; pompous faculty who think they know everything and that the world revolves around them; no upward mobility unless you are one of the few "highly favored" by senior administration; parking is $100+/month; no work/life balance - you are expected to answer your phone and emails 24/7/365.  Students are impossibly demanding, have emotional issues, and act like staff is their servants.  Parents act the same if not worse.

review_title: Not for everyone; certainly not for me.
pros: High-prestige university and a big name in graduate business schools. Benefits were excellent; pay was good.
cons: Raises were non-existent for the 3 years I was there, though that was supposedly due to the economic crunch. Faculty is, with notable exceptions, highly aware of their status and prestige, and treat support staff as underlings and nuisances. Managerial skills vary by department, but there seemed to be a disproportionate number of power-conscious blowhards who impose petty demands for the sake of proving they can.

pros:
Colleagues across campus were interested not only in doing a great job but learning how to prove.
Because of university's location, staff seemed united. There was enthusiasm about partnering with other areas. Although top leadership was not always visible, there was never any doubt about University or department goals. A beautiful campus and the opportunity to work with very smart people.
cons: Autonomy of departments sometimes means that university policies are ignored. As with every organization, there are one or two staff who fail to work effectively and blame others for their failures. At UC these folks are few and far between, but there. It's not easy to get to with public transportation,.

pros: This job is very laid back. They’re telling the truth when noting that you won’t work more than 37.5 hrs a week so it’s a great job to have when you have other obligations. The culture is friendly and people are helpful. I never had to bring home work or work overtime. If you were a stressed out finance analyst (as I was), this is a great job for you to step back, regroup, and figure out what you actually want to do with your life.
cons: The work is repetitive and can be mundane at times. It’s pretty easy to become bored so store up some podcasts to listen to while doing work.

review_title: Diverse Community, Full Workload.....Little room for growth
pros:
Diversity! No two employees are the same....the opportunities to work with people of all backgrounds is a valuable professional experience I enjoyed.

Constant Workload- Never boring.

Sense of community - working for a University was fresh and innovative in some areas
cons:
Compensation!  I was never paid my worth and ultimately decided to leave due to that reason. 

Political- some senior leaders in some units take their job a little serious and act almost snobby. Its not a corporate world so some of the stringent decision making standards and stiff communication need to be relaxed.

No room for growth-not many options for growth in individual units except for administrative roles, and transferring between units is very competitive.

review_title: Reality doesn't live up to its top-notch scholastic reputation
pros: UC provides opportunities to work with many brilliant and inspiring people, including many from diverse backgrounds and from other countries. The university's name also carries a lot of weight- more so as you get farther away from Chicago. Campus is historic and beautiful.
cons:
Inconvenient and sometimes dangerous location, constant turf wars, incompetent career administrators, no consequences for unethical behavior by managers and physicians, lack of pathways to advancement for most staff, culture of individual achievement, poor compensation, inadequate staff parking, most openings are only posted publicly as a formality.
Staff education benefits are laughable for a university.

job_title: Research Specialist II in Chicago, IL
pros: The amount of cutting-edge research that goes on at University of Chicago is incredible.  The number of researchers with Nobel Prizes is telling of the University's status as a premier research institution.  It is very cool to have those types of resources at your fingertips.
cons: There were moments when I felt like it was the true "ivory tower."  The research that is done is important, but if you do not fit with the University's ethos--living in Hyde Park, going to events, living a certain lifestyle, a person can feel like they don't fit in.  I met, and had to work with many snobs.    Also, since there is so much pressure for publication and bringing in grant money, PIs are often absent.

review_title: Wealth of resources, networks, & learning opportunities
pros: Opportunities for learning, campus environment, exceptional libraries, quality of intellectual collaboration
cons: Salary (as is typical in academia) cannot compete with industry; slow to advance careers; lacking in African American and female intellectual leadership in numerous divisions, which has overall negative impacts on culture.

review_title: Not a good place to work here as staff- I know very few people who enjoy working here
pros: Good vacation benefits and health insurance. This is a prestigious university which attracts some of the brightest and interesting students that I have encountered.
cons: People do not get recognition for the work they do. Compensation is quite low here, and it is very hard to advance here. Being a staff member at this university really is horrible and I know administration in many different parts of the university who are unhappy. Senior Management is horrible, the people who are in power are failed Ph.D's who could not get tenure-track teaching jobs and are now administrators. Fake and back-stabbing coworkers. All in all, not a happy place to work. Morale is bad.

review_title: Top tier university to be affiliated with, but lacking in a couple areas
pros: World-class faculty, very informative seminars, beautiful campus with many historical buildings, three weeks vacation/year instead of two for staff, multiple insurance options, easy public transportation to the campus during weekday rush periods
cons: surrounded by bad areas, poor median pay for science technologists compared to other top-rated universities, not very many places off of campus to eat, public transportation to the university on the weekends is difficult

review_title: I provided library services to people and offices, with a specialization in mixed technologies.
pros: The community is a major pro. The workforce and university community is diverse, intelligent, and highly motivated. These attributed translate to innovation in the workplace. The University of Chicago also offers very good health and financial planning benefits.
cons: Salaries for non-faculty staff are lower than in non-academic sectors. Due to its size and the close-knit nature of its tributary professional associations the University is prone to organizational inertia and top heaviness with  somewhat limited opportunities for advancement. Tensions between unions and adminstration have led to a system where team performance is not rewarded.

review_title: Go elsewhere if you have the flexibility!
pros: Good benefits. Smart students. An effort to be competitive.
cons: Doe not base promotion on quality but rather on service. Would into know a truly cutting edge idea in the development stages, if a thousand people told them. They hire AFTER you have made an achievement, not before. Luckily, I was one of the few who was hired based on my achievement, but not many really are. And the really top notch people go to Stanford, Penn, Harvard or  Princeton.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work but now very demoralizing.
pros: Fairly good health benefits. Interesting academic and cultural events always happening on campus. Excellent pay (but only if you are a high-level administrator; otherwise it's mediocre at best).
cons: Staff salaries frozen at or below the rate of inflation since 2008; pensions suspended last year; constant threats of downsizing and cuts due to introduction of shared services model. The administration views workers as exploitable and disposable.

pros: University of Chicago has decent affordable options for health-care insurance including flexible spending accounts and life insurance. Flexible work hours make the life / work balance easier.
cons: University of Chicago has limited "perk" benefits for staff, non-faculty.  For example, UofC will pay college tuition for children of faculty and senior staff to any school and where in the country. Families of staff need to fun 100% of their children's college costs with no help from UofC. There is a slight discount in tuition if the child goes to UofC for undergraduate studies. Limited promotion and training opportunities for staff employees. Located at Argonne National Lab, the UofC salaries are not up-to-par with ANL salaries.

pros: There are decent health benefits
cons: Salaries for most positions are frozen at or below the rate of inlation, so if you stay in the same position for several years, you will see a stagnation or gradual reduction in your real income. You may become a highly talented and indispensable employee, but you can forget about ever seeing a raise. The attitude of management seems to be that if you remain in the same position for more than 5 years, you're a loser.

review_title: Wonderful if you can find the right fit!
job_title: Associate Director of Finance in Chicago, IL
pros: Benefits are good. Environment can be very flexible and relaxed. Beautiful campus.
cons: Decentralized. More focus/care given to faculty and student needs from a central level. Staff are often considered last although they support the majority of the work/needs. Certain sections/departments are notorious for high demands, long hours, and not treating staff well.

review_title: Overall a great place to work
pros: Excellent benefits, competitive pay, leisurely/academic atmosphere, great people, opportunities for advancement and growth
cons: Part of the culture in that needs of faculty are always placed before needs of staff. Staff are definitely considered second class citizens. Also the opportunity for training on campus has shifted from free to quite expensive. When I first started here I took a ton of classes in computer programs that really benefited my position and department. I have not taken any in the past several years because they charge a pretty hefty fee for these on campus trainings now.

job_title: Clinic Licensed Practical Nurse Senior in Chicago, IL
pros: The Benefits are the only good thing
cons: Very racist place to work and they will not pay LPNs what they are worth. My manager asked me to do things that were very unethical and could potentially cause harm to my nursing licences. The University of Chicago is very clickish and will down talk, and be very demeaning to there employees. I was asked to resign after i told my manager that i would not do unethical things. So i resigned. You win some and you lose some.

review_title: Overall, being a postdoc at UofC has been a positive experience.
pros: The Bioscience Division's postdoctoral community is very strong here, thanks in part to their Postdoctoral Association (PDA).  The PDA hosts seminars and other events that focus on career development, training, and social activities.  The benefits offered with the job are also very good, especially medical, dental and vision insurance (one of the best plans I've ever seen).
cons: Some of the department's administrative offices are better than others.  For my department, the staff is a mixed bag.  Some are on top of their game while the others lag behind (especially HR).  Getting reimbursed for job-related expenditures has been tough at times.

pros:
Majority of the faculty are very friendly and down to earth.
Most departments have flexibility as far as personal appointments and time off.
Opportunity for professional development and growth
cons:
There are sometimes budgetary issues when inquiring about an increase in pay.
Differing information from HR, your direct supervisor, and the Union (if you are in one) in regards to pay, disciplinary action, etc.
The job postings value a bachelor's degree more than actual experience which puts ones with an abundance of years of experience in the Admin professional field at a disadvantage in comparison to those with a Bachelor's degree who may not have any experience.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: When you're at a good school in advanced classes, and this is the way you start doing something on your own. Even if you don't want to stay in Academia for your whole life, it's a good first experience with working while using what you learned.
cons: The professor / research group may not turn out the right match for you. But that can happen in a company as well, and it would be more difficult to leave then.

pros: Exciting mission, smart people, good benefits
cons: Job requirements have become more and more specialized while job parameters and areas of expertise per job have expanded exponentially. Jobs start at lower pay than previously.  Salary advancement per annum generally limited to 2%.  Institution slanted to hiring experts from outside rather than advancing from within.  Many, but not all, academics, have no clue how to motivate or manage employees.  Recent experience is that there is very little loyalty to long term employees.

pros: The university can provide great opportunities for research with some of the top people in the field. There are many possibilities to get involved in other professional activities as well.
cons: Many of the academic advisors are relatively apathetic towards the students' and their overall success, and some are downright toxic. Due to poorly structured doctoral programs with little departmental oversight, in some cases this can leave students with little to no recourse if their advisor happens to be one of the toxic ones.

review_title: I guess it's worth it if "University of Chicago Booth" being on your resume means something to you.
pros:
The benefits are stellar. Period. They have everything from a killer health care package (no pun intended) to several thousands of dollars in home buying assistance, to half off of tuition (which is STILL a lot of money) - the best compensation package I've seen so far. 

I thoroughly enjoyed my co-workers. The group that was there when I worked there was very supportive of one another and collaborative when allowed to be. 

The department is small. You get to carry a project to it's completion, and are usually the only developer working on it. 

The company is about 'fit'. If you fit in, you're golden.
cons:
Extremenly high turnover rate - and this department in particular has the highest of the school.

No real professional development offered - not even within the team. They TELL YOU that they are all about growth and professional development in the interview, but that's just to get you in the door. This was the general consensus amongst my co-workers.

Middle Managment is not as technically competent as they should be to make the decisions they are making about the methodologies and standards (or lack thereof) they employ. The development is way behind the times in terms of standards and best practices. As a developer, you will stagnate. Any suggestions made while I was employed there were disregarded because Managment was not familiar with the technology, and not willing to allow us the time to explore and grow.

The department is small. You get to carry a project to it's completion, and are usually the only developer. So, you are most often over worked. Expectations are set for clients by PMs who have no idea how to set timelines. The timlines are mismanaged and production time is always waisted early on. Then, as the developer, you are inevitably expected to make up the time on your end. There is always a project backlog that forces very aggressive deadlines (but this does not translate into job security). And there is no QA process. You are asked to QA your own websites - which is a bit like having a fox watch the hen house - but then, there is no real time set aside for this. You are expected to multitask and crank out projects inside of unrealistic deadlines - but it better be perfect or it's counted against you. And while many of us developers are very good and meticulous, we all make mistakes, and sometimes, under duress we don't catch them all.

The company is about "fit" - even more than it is about keeping good talent. If at any point in time, for any reason management feels like you no longer "fit" - regardless of your work product, or whether or not the reason is legitimate - you will be surreptitiously pushed out. I've seen it happen more than once.

The atmoshpere in the office that I worked in was often adversarial and tense. Management had a passive aggressive - and at times condescending management style. Most members of the team had complained about their treatment or the way that they have witnessed others being treated at one time or another. Almost always it was described as "unfair" or "petty".

pros: The faculty are very supportive of students who are interested in research. It's easy to approach labs, and most will take on undergrads with minimal experience. Undergrads get to participate in lab meetings and get hands-on research experience. There are often opportunities for summer and post-grad employment. Most labs are open to their undergrad research assistants completing honors work towards a senior project in the lab, often in conjunction with a graduate student.
cons: Some labs expect undergrads to complete a considerable amount of administrative or secretarial work, in addition to research tasks. As an undergraduate, there are few opportunities for advancement.

pros: the benefits of working at a university are great. We get 4 weeks per year from the get go, although this is not increased until 10 years of being in the job.
cons: HR leaves a lot to be desired. Not only are they slow, they also are difficult to post new positions. It is policy to wait after someone leaves to make sure the people left behind cannot do the job before the position is posted. So those who are left are overstretched and end up leaving because of the poor conditions.

review_title: I realize that job satisfaction varies widely across departments.  My dissatisfaction stems from our non-responsive HR.
pros: Surrounded by inquisitive and energetic students, low stress, plenty of lunchtime lectures and other interesting events on campus, good work-life balance, staff access to various facilities (e.g. athletic facilities, libraries)
cons: The amount of red tape is wholly overwhelming.  University systems, routines, and databases are slow, clunky, and outdated.  There is little room for career growth and the salary is mediocre.  To make matters worse, HR is avoidant and makes many empty promises.  Again, experience differs greatly from department to department.

pros: This is a good place for collaborations, access to many facilities for research, and some help with professional development. The benefits are decent enough.
cons: There is a big pressure not to take vacation days or sick days even if they are designated for use. The publish or die culture is still there but depending on the department or lab, the pressure will vary. There are a few stereotypes associated with the university that may make it difficult to approach certain positions at smaller universities or colleges. The tendency of having stress related issues seem high.

review_title: Great if you can find an advancement opportunity...
pros: Great People! Great Environment! Most positions offer a lot of autonomy and the facilities are nice. They are starting to develop flexible work schedules, which is a definite plus.
cons: Limited growth opportunities. You sit in a meeting every year where they tell you just how few people are able to move up within the organization. It's a bit of a letdown to know that when you do want to advance, the opportunity will not likely be there.

review_title: I enjoyed working with University of Chicago, I enjoyed working with CPS as a partner with the university in working wit
pros: The culture environment  with the employees was very good.  The have  team work environment.
cons: The challengers of working with the survey lab would be with Chicago Public Schools. Working with the different high schools with high school student  can be ca challenge.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Opportunities for growth, strong learning environment, good work/life balance.  My supervisors were almost always reasonable, understanding, supportive and kind.  Job goals and timelines were reachable.  Stress was at a reasonable level at most times.
cons: Experience can vary widely between supervisors, even within same department.  Compensation does not always match education/experience level.  Some supervisors do not prioritize research work over clinical work, which could make the job difficult.  If your area of research is not oncology, you will not get any recognition or funding from higher-ups.

pros: I work at the Becker-Friedman Institute. Really rewarding work, as I'm the only research assistant on my project, but I can see how that might depend entirely on the professor you end up working with. Flexible hours and decent pay.
cons: Work can be really demanding and really stressful, particularly as a part-time job, there are just times you need to clock in more than 10 hours a week to get the job done but you're not going to get paid for more than 10 hours of work.

pros: campus is beautiful & my PI is great. we have access to everything we need to be able to work quickly and happily. hyde park is green and has easy access to lots of beach & parks.
cons: admin is cumbersome (lots of paperwork & shifting structures). staff can be condescending and sexist. work environment varies highly lab to lab, but mine is good. housing in the neighborhood is ample but expensive and of varying quality (there are bed bugs so look carefully!).

review_title: Not bad, but certainly not the best experience
pros: Great co-workers, beautiful campus, well respected academic institution, benefits were also good.  The University is also doing some great things with the regentrification of 53rd street.
cons: There seems to be very high turnover in some parts of the University.  I know that in one department in particular where they have had 11 people leave from April 1 - August 1, several were long term employees which is always a bit concerning.

review_title: Toxic- It's not just a Britney Spears song.
job_title: Assistant Director Development in Chicago, IL
pros:
Relationships with peers tend to become very strong, as many times we have had to rely heavily on one another to complete tasks and projects- which tend to come down with pressure and very last-minute.

I have made friendships with co-workers that I treasure and who have understood how difficult working at UChicago has been.

UChicago looks nice on a resume- but was not worth it in exchange for the deplorable working environment.
cons:
I like to consider myself a true optimist- but this is the absolute worst working environment I've ever been in. I almost don't know where to begin...

Advancement opportunities are rare, and promotions have been given to those people who (among other things) verbally abuse their coworkers and have been documented incidents during my time there. For a promotion, the worker is almost always a white male (which seems to contradict the "diverse working environment" UChicago likes to tout) and appears to always have an unusually close relationship with their boss. In other words, the "yes" man is alive and well in this office.

The actual team dynamic is disastrous. Micro-management is considered effective management, and I (along with my coworkers) were not trusted to make any type of decisions over programming whatsoever. Ironically, mistakes or failures would then be attributed to the same staff who did not have any control/decision making over those processes to begin with. While HR is aware of team issues and the horrible morale, no steps have been taken to address the situation- and supervisors have never openly recognized it with staff.

Trust between staff and management is non-existent. I have been made aware of examples when my supervisor has given me directions (which I had in handwriting from them), and then in my following through on those directions, denied any involvement (and blamed me) to those higher-up when it became a problem. "Throwing Under the Bus" could be an Olympic sport- and my career at UChicago suffered when I refused to participate (along with some of my coworkers). Staff are very rarely, if ever, thanked for their job. While it seems small, just knowing that someone/anyone recognized my work would have really made a difference in how I felt about my job there.

Any type of disagreement/criticism with management is severely frowned upon- there have been meetings where people have been expressly asked not to bring any of their issues/concerns to management as they will not be considered (for being too "negative" in nature). However, a condescending tone with staff is a hallmark of the office culture. The irony.

For a prestigious university with such a hefty endowment (approx. $6.67 billion dollars), as well as the pressure of hitting high goals (with an understaffed team), compensation is significantly less than at local/peer institutions. If you're in development and are looking for competitive pay, you will not find it at UChicago.

Underneath the shiny veneer of our logo, the University of Chicago has proven to me that no matter what your non-profit status is or how altruistic your mission statement may be, it exists as a quagmire of the worst aspects of a job. Arrogance, favoritism, sexism, duplicity and opportunism  lives within the walls of their development offices.

review_title: Talk to someone who's worked in your department before signing
pros: The University has a great benefits plan and some great employees throughout the different departments. Most departments and divisions are well-run with most student facing roles actually invested in the success of the students. Also, because of the size of the University it is very easy to advance in your career and develop a strong professional network.
cons: The size of the University makes it difficult to establish a unified culture or experience so one department or division may be your best job ever with great opportunities for personal and professional growth while another may have poor management or limited interest in investing in your career.

review_title: Working hear has been the best experience.
job_title: IT Support Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Very family oriented. My manager is very understanding when I have to take off due to emergencies. My manager is very fair and doesn't micromanage. The company is easily accessible from major bus and train routes
cons: Hard to find parking. The University is not located in a very safe neighborhood. We often hear reports of assaults and robberies. There is a University side and a Hospital side. I would recommend applying for all jobs on the university side. The Hospital is a lot more restricted.

review_title: It's a fine place to work as IT staff, but difficult to improve and grow
pros:
Good benefits for staff and academics
Relaxed environment as a non-profit organization
Great place to work until retirement
A lot of opportunities for young people to start somewhere
cons:
Certainly not the best place for IT career development
Not much room for promotions
Salaries are below the average for the IT industry
No bonuses or other monetary incentives as this is a non-profit organization  
Very difficult to fine good talented people to place on the team and keep them long enough
It's frustrating to work with HR and the university bureaucracy in general

review_title: Decent place to be an research assistant
pros:
-work with some of the very best scholars in your field on really interesting projects
-professors here really care about your career goals and are often willing to help with them
cons:
-like any other university, the experience depends a lot on the professor and assignment
-if possible, find someone doing something similar to the work you would like to do in the future; otherwise, they won't be able to help much with future career opportunities
-if you're at the U of Chicago, you probably already have an insane workload; ask if this is something you have time for, and if it is something worth the time it will take

review_title: Some great aspects, some not so great
pros: Fabulous colleagues, intellectually stimulating, super students, supportive of exciting and (some) innovative projects. “Life of the mind” means great opportunities for developing projects and engaging colleagues within and beyond institution.
cons: Can be stodgy, slow to support pursuits that are not within known and well trod rubrics ie those that expand their “life of the mind” rhetoric. Salaries not kept on par with cost of living or based on merit rather must get outside offer to see any increase.

pros: Flexible work environment with a lot of room for creativity and personal growth if you are a go-getter.  Pay and benefits are not bad, especially for a university.  Laid back environment in a nice campus.
cons: Generally, benefits and salary are not equal to that jobs in corporate environments.  Alums/faculty/students are self-important and demanding.  Office space situation is sub par.  Management is top heavy, lot of directors, not much communication between groups leads to infighting and squabbles over 'turf'.  Neighborhood surrounding campus is very dangerous, high crime rate.

review_title: Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics - Reseach
pros: Everyone who works at KICP is incredibly kind, curious, and intelligent. People are excited to discuss physics concepts and it is very easy to find people willing to give advice about graduate school, fellowships, and things of that sort.
cons: The hours can be a bit erratic, some weeks there is not enough to do, while other weeks it seems impossible to manage the workload. It takes a good deal of schedule flexibility to be an effective researcher

pros: Experience teaching, preparing lectures, interacting with undergrads in different areas of the department, and it does provide some if very little compensation.
cons: Expectations on what the department wanted out of the course were not communicated well. Students that were more self-sufficient did not need the course, but had to take it anyway, and were thus dead weight in the class. Often, advisors' demands and stylistic conventions were at odd with my own, which tied my hands. U of C undergrads are know-it-alls anyway.

review_title: Good for career growth but I wouldn't want to stay there too long.
job_title: Assistant Director, Development and Alumni Relations in Chicago, IL
pros: The university is known throughout the world and can assist you when applying employment with another company.
cons: The employees are very elitist and have a high opinion of what they do.  This in not necessarily a bad thing but it can come off that way.  The organization is also very large so it is hard for you to not feel like a cog in the machine.

pros: There are always many open positions in the IT dept due to the constant revolving door of personnel.   It's a good place to get some skills and then move on.  Looks good on your resume.
cons: IT management and structure is constantly changing with no clear strategy.   Positions and people are re-organized based on the changing whims of the persnickety CIO and the executive staff she enables.  Favoritism, nepotism and the "good old girl" mentality is rampant.

pros:
-Not much micro-management, extremely flexible working hours (especially in the Winter and Spring quarters) 
-Basic student health insurance and tuition remission are covered. 
-Usually, great office space (typically shared with one other preceptor) 
-Fun and challenging work with M.A. students from a variety of academic/life backgrounds
cons:
-Teaching and administrative duties often exceed 19.5 hours/week, especially in the Autumn quarter. 
-Student Life Fee (about $350/quarter) is not covered. 
-It's by no means a "bad job," but you're on your own. Job training consists of one day-long orientation where you're overloaded with information is difficult to retain; after that, guidance and mentorship is minimal. 
-Overall morale and cohesiveness is low; most preceptors are advanced grad students and everyone is insanely busy, all the time. 
-When there are problems with the old building (which have been ample; the heating system is a disaster and can make the office unbearable) they are ignored because there isn't a clear solution and it doesn't seem worth the time to go through the cumbersome system for maintenance requests. 
-Working with MA students is rewarding, but their academic preparation varies so widely that it's difficult to keep everyone on the same page during discussion sections and workshops. Standards for admission have decreased in recent years; the administration has responded to increased financial pressures by making more admits, which increases preceptors' work load. 
-Program administration has become very focused on recruiting and advertising, and less on the Program's academic vision. 
-Sometimes you receive additional work obligations without much warning (e.g., evaluating additional admissions files, attending interviews for new hires). 
-Increased admission of foreign students (especially since U of C opened its Center in Beijing, and with the university's financial issues) who don't have much of a support system means they sometimes come to you with dicey or sensitive problems that you aren't trained to deal with; also, different academic/social norms (such as boundaries around talking about others' appearance in a university/professional setting) have led to uncomfortable gender dynamics in office hours. 
-Staff meetings are not conducive environment for addressing the above issues. They're usually focused on administrative issues that could be dealt with much more quickly than they are. Staff's concerns are often bracketed or shut down.

pros: You are working with some of the most intelligent people in the world in one of the top research institutions in the country.
cons: Especially given the current funding climate, there is an incredible pressure to produce data and the climate is surprisingly corporate - but without the monetary rewards and consistent 9-5 schedule that would be found in industry.

review_title: Great atmosphere, company doing great work you can be passionate about
pros: The Crime Lab works on interesting projects and everyone who I've interacted with is very professional and efficient. People are dedicated to the research projects they work on. I worked mostly independently in high schools across the city and the Crime Lab paid for my transportation. The work they do is fascinating, and the people are all friendly and public service minded.
cons: This is a great company to work for and I can't think of any cons. I worked here during college and they were very flexible with working around my schedule.

pros: For students, it is easier to work for the University because they operate on the same calendar and tend to be more understanding about academic deadlines.
cons: I wish the University would just extend financial aid to students who qualify for work-study instead of having us work through the work-study program. After working steadily through college, I find myself at an academic disadvantage compared to students from more well-off backgrounds that have not worked a day in their college careers.

review_title: A decent place to hold a part-time job while you're a student
job_title: Technical Processing Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Everyone at the University is very smart and intellectual. Since this is such a prestigious university, you will meet very important people during your time there, and the majority of the staff that works there are usually students.
cons: Sometimes, working there can be a bit boring, since the culture is very different from other places. "The place where fun comes to die" is applicable not only to the academic arena there but also when you work there, except in places where they only employ people not affiliated with the University (such as the cafes).

job_title: Senior Software Developer in Chicago, IL
pros: Good work life balance.  The long term benefits are fantastic.  Supporting a university who's research and graduates make a real difference is also rewarding.
cons: Lower average salaries than private companies.  That combined with such a focus on long term benefits seems to not bring about enough change in policy, people, and execution.  Different colleges and groups within the university act as independent silos too often with internal politics trumping reason in many scenarios.

review_title: Working for at the University of Chicago was one of the BEST  experiences I have had.
pros: One of the best reasons to work for the University of Chicago is the knowledge that you are among some of the world's top experts in various fields of medicine. The doctors and staff treat everyone with kindness and respect.
cons: The only downside to my work experience at the University of Chicago was that each position was a temporary position.

pros: open, time flexible, people here are nice and friendly. The salary is relatively good comparing to other universities. Benefits are great.
cons: Consistency,  Sometimes consistency can be a great thing and may provide a person a sense of security, but other times it may start to become a little boring. Think about what kind of mental stimulation your job gives you and decide if you are burnt out at work or happy with the expected routine.

pros:
If you connect with the right folks, UChicago can be an amazingly collegial opportunity to work with incredibly smart, good-hearted and dedicated people.  Internally and externally the UChicago network is outstanding and can open lots of doors to other opportunities.  The intellectual atmosphere of the University is in a stratosphere of its own in the region. 
The employee benefits are outstanding.
cons: UChicago can be frustratingly bureaucratic, and for all the brains at the place, some of the people who work there do their jobs without a sense of mission befitting such a preeminent institution.

job_title: Residential Computing Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: I work 6 hours per week for a $750 quarterly stipend. The work is pretty easy and I have required a great deal of computer knowledge to assist student with tech support issues even though it is my job.
cons: My boss originally decreased my pay from the first few quarters that I worked at ResCom when we look at how much each RCA was being paid per hour.

pros: The research environment is great and very supportive. Communications and collaborations between coworkers from different departments are encouraged. People are friendly and very laid back.
cons: The Hyde Park location could be a bit isolating and the housing options are very limited. There is not a whole of things going on in Hyde Park. Limited options for food and dining as well.

review_title: A great place for self-motivated graduate students, but very limited career direction
pros:
In the biomedical sciences at least, the program is well-funded. Students are given a fair stipend, basic medical insurance, and have minimal TA requirements - the university clearly wants their students to focus on research. However, as with any graduate program, much of your success hinges on the lab environment, and the PI in particular. Resources (machines, information, etc) are abound, but generally need to be sought-out, which means knowing who to talk to, or spending a considerable amount of time asking around - which is not necessarily a bad thing, since it encourages development of networking skills. 

Work/life balance can be tough, but this should not be unexpected in a doctoral program. Still, there is ample flexibility in most labs with respect to schedules, and most PIs do not care whether you come in at 8am or noon, as long as the data consistently flows. Just keep in mind that taking a month or two off probably will result in a several-month delay in graduation, so in the end, time management is your responsibility. Most weeks are 50+ hours, but time passes quickly with good labmates and an interesting project.
cons:
Funding, funding, funding. Not your own, but that of your lab's. Make sure the lab you join has adequate funding, lest you end up in the unenviable position of having to switch labs midway into your degree. 

Lack of career development and networking. If you have intentions of doing anything other than a postdoc after graduation, good luck. Industry ties are weak at best, and there is almost no support for non-research career paths. Career development seminars are a joke, since advice can be had in plenty online, and what you really need are the personal contacts, which you will not get from a generic presentation in an auditorium filled with desperate postdocs and senior grad students. A word to the wise - start networking in any way you can starting no later than the 3rd year of your program. Even if you intend to do a postdoc, make sure you end up in a lab with contacts that will be conducive to your future career growth, unless the thought of being a "research associate" or whatever postdocs who stay past the expected 2-3 years are called.

review_title: Great place to start a career
pros:
(a) Access to awesome institutions, perks, libraries, people, faculty, buildings, events, etc.!
(b) Great community of nerdy/geeky people seeking to create and add to knowledge.
(c) See item (a).
cons:
(a) Very stratified, hierarchical work structure that makes it difficult to move up the ladder.
(b) Mounds upon mounds of red tape to get anything accomplished.
(c) Very little openness to change (though new ideas are encouraged, which can be frustrating).

review_title: Great benefits, pretty good working environment, but little professional growth opportunities
pros:
Great benefits
Teamsters union for a number of library jobs
Great library HR
Pay for student workers and staff is good
1/2 tuition discount for FT staff (still is expensive, though)
Many library departments have good communication and good bosses
Interdepartmental communication is pretty good
Almost everyone is very friendly and helpful
UCPD is good
University is careful with budget and endowment. The downturn has caused some financial tightness, but it's far less trouble than what other universities face.
Strong internal hiring for positions
cons:
Difficult to move up. You can, but it takes a while. You may need to leave and come back with additional experience to get the higher-level positions, like a librarian position.

There will be a few people here and there who are only "ok" employees, and people who are difficult to work with, and they can make a department less fun to work with. Nothing terribly dysfunctional, though. The vast majority are great to work with.

Needs improvement in collaborative communication, like wikis

pros: Working with the faculty on a regular basis was an interesting and unique opportunity.  You realize how many brilliant minds there are on campus.  When classes are in session, there is a real sense of energy on campus that makes it a fun place to work.
cons: The trip to and from work via public transportation can be brutal in anything less than ideal weather.  The campus also tends to feel very isolated from the rest of the city.  The administration is enormous, so it can be easy to get lost in the crowd.

review_title: depends on what lab you're in
job_title: Research Specialist in Glendale Heights, IL
pros: Working in academia typically offers a good way to learn a variety of protocols and use many instruments. Especially at a large University, you have the freedom to basically try anything. The schedule is usually pretty awesome as well.
cons: Academic research is not a good career path, you're basically a technician forever.
