I was not given any incentive to perform my duties well, it was like nobody cared about anything, which was really demoralizing. If I got a bad review, nothing happened. If I got a good review, nothing happened. I was generally very unhappy there.

review_title: If you valued your RAs liked you claimed to, treat them like you do.
pros: Being an RA itself can be extraordinarily rewarding for the residents, the Resident Heads, and the bonds to be formed with other RAs.
cons:
Resident Assistants are told that they are the cream of the crop and essential to the UChicago experience, but definitely are not treated as such. The Assistant Directors that run HRL make it seem like they value the input of RAs but it is very clear that they do not, they hand down rules that are harmful to RAs and the house communities that they serve without any input and are surprised when they are objections. 

In addition, the vetting process for becoming an RA does not prevent any Title IX offenders from becoming RAs which is extraordinarily dangerous considering how much influence an RA has in their housing community— I know of at least one offender who almost become an RA but dropped out of the process of his own will, probably because other people knew he was an offender as well. 

RAs are also underpaid for the work they do, and the low pay combined with the hours and responsibilities creates a barrier to entry that the upper management is terribly offended by whenever it is brought up. 

This all was bad enough, but the treatment of RAs during the coronavirus pandemic has just been flat out terrible— they initially took away their salaries and only restored them after public outcry in the form of petitions and letters. 

Now the 2020 fall policy for new RAs to be stationed inside dorms with the implied expectation that they enforce social distancing puts the in physical danger, and shows that HRL does not actually care about the well-being about RAs (who are also just students!). They also are having RAs responsible for moving furniture for on-campus residents that is ship beforehand, which should be left to trained movers.

pros: 1. Good health insurance and benefits, 2. Associated with great university, 3. Great tuition reimbursement if you do not have a BSN or if you are accepted into graduate school there, 4. Great tuition discounts for children who attend the high school or college
cons: 1. Parking is terrible and costly, and is probably only going to get worse, 2. Hard to move up and recognized for achievements (most jobs are dead-ends), 3. Salary is not competitive

pros:
-amply amount of feedback
-plenty of room for professional growth
-plenty of contacts and good networking
-beautiful facility with open resources to use
-friendly and accessible staff
cons:
-not very engaging work
-without self-motivation, lack of any incentive to work
-changes in company often go past interns and advisors unless you ask

job_title: Administrative Assistant & Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Lovely library and fine location.
cons: Abusive management styles and modes of interpersonal interaction dominate this work environment.  Frequent physical aggression between faculty and directed at staff (i.e. shouting, slamming doors, hitting walls/doorways, cursing, domineering invasions of personal space and affects).  Frequent passive-aggressive physical violations, apparently aimed at condescension, coming from from faculty and directed at staff (unwelcome & patronizing touch, infantilizing communication by tone and content, power projection using body positioning - cornering, kneeling, hovering).  Frequent psychological abuse from and between faculty and among staff by position of power (i.e. unmasked sexist and racist remarks, nearly constant scapegoating of most vulnerable staff, high-intensity psychological sweat-shopping).  Human resources necessarily cooperative with abusive management and, as such, non-protective of employee rights to safe working environment.

pros: Unfortunately i do not have much to state but I feel diversity and the benefits are decent and I did meet few good folks in dept and some good people across campus.
cons: No transparency and lack of quality leadership who only cares for their own upward mobility and allows bad direct reports to mistreat colleagues, lower management and below.  Low retention; revolving door on all levels.

pros: Worked part time in the computing lab. It is a pretty laid back job, with more often than not nothing to be done while sitting behind the desk, giving you free time to do other work.
cons: Some of the people you work with are difficult to get along with. If you don't become friends with the managers you feel left out during meetings.

review_title: So far it is going very well. Beautiful campus, great department.
pros: You get a lot of guidance from advisors and other students. As a grad student you get a nice work area and plenty of guidance and structure. I am just starting but already have an idea of the big picture
cons: Weather is a bit taxing. Also it is not in the nicest of neighborhoods. It would also be nice if there were more textbooks available for common use.

review_title: Great Program and great work experience
job_title: Senior Program Director in Chicago, IL
pros: The program directors have created a culture in which the staff are valued and the students we served (approx. 250  to 350 graduate students) are well taken care of and treated with respect.  Great colleagues, lots of independence. I felt enabled to provide top quality service to my clients and could feel good about my work every day. What more can you ask for?
cons: There was no downside to this job.

pros: Intelligent, passionate colleagues who get things done. Highly respected institution. Semi-flexible schedule options .
cons:
Inconvenient location if you live anywhere but Hyde Park. Parking lots are expensive, but street parking is almost impossible, and public transportation is difficult to come by. Cramped old buildings not particularly conducive to productivity. 

Other cons definitely depend on your division within the university.

review_title: Great work environment, but very high expectations
pros: I work in a very small subdivision in which there are only really 5 or so permanent full-time employees. This helps cultivate a friendly work environment, and the intellectual abilities of my colleagues are great to work with. Also, having the name on your resume looks incredibly prestigious.
cons: Expect way too much for one person in regards to work load. Unconventional hours and extremely high expectations due to lower number of staff members creates a lot of stress.

review_title: Good place to work, but not to advance your career
pros: Working with smart and high energy people. Good benefits and pay.  Campus life is fun -- a lot of things going on outside of work (plays, art shows, lectures, athletic facilitites)
cons: Senior management is disfunctional.  Everything must go through the faculty Dean's office and they don't have a clue what staff life is like -- they are all academes.  The Dean himself is great, but the other 3 are more concerned about themselves to manage effectively.

review_title: Calm setting, great benefits package. Knowledgable staff.
pros: Knowledgable staff within the setting of high education facility. The staff  at the University are warm great people who listen. From the Facilities Services staff that takes care of the campus in and out to the staff and professors along with the students who attend the school the University takes pride in this philosophy and practice.
cons: No room for growth or promotion.

pros: Great benefits!!! This hospital has great medical, dental and educational benefits.  The health care is really top of the line.
cons: There is to many people that hire relatives.  This slows the growth of the company.  The staff wants to top of the line but they hold on to old ideas.  HR is joke so when looking for job make sure you align with your direct supervisor.

review_title: UChicago has the resources, but not the mentality to be the best at what it does.
pros: Resources, low cost of living, little to do in Hyde Park but to work, Administration is very nice, UChicago provides a lot of assistance to help you find a career, People are supportive
cons: Healthcare benefits for employees are much more expensive than comparable benefits elsewhere. The university seems niggard with regard to facility maintenance. The library has many electronic resources, but they are not always listed on its website (you have to search to find them).

review_title: An elite University with a culture problem
pros: Access to immense resources and high quality colleagues
cons: A fish rots from the head down. The University has a big culture problem. Colleagues across many departments all report feeling disposable and expendable. Despite having a multi-billion dollar endowment the University essentially terminated all retirement matching for postdocs, who are already overworked, underpaid, and under appreciated.

pros: Good benefits, staff in my area are generally great to work with and have been around for a while.  Enough opportunities for advancement in my field-- UChicago likes to hire and promote its own when possible.
cons: Pay is lousy compared to private sector.  Hyde Park is okay, not ideal.  The University can be a big place-- not a lot of cohesion.

job_title: Senior Research Professional in Chicago, IL
pros: There are great opportunities to expand your mind as the place is full of brilliant people. Also, if you work in the area of medical/social science research you have opportunities for being part of outside-the-box thinking with folks who aren't afraid to step outside their comfort zone.
cons: The bureaucracy here at times can rock your world but once you learn the culture and you work with people you admire, respect and like, you can survive.

pros: You get a chance to work with some brilliant professors and co-workers. The perfect job for people considering graduate school in psychology. A job like this lets you work with grad students and see what life will be like if you choose to do a PhD program. Hours are relaxing and the work isn't stressful.
cons: You can get better pay at other jobs. There really is room is grow. The job is meant to be for people in between undergrad and grad school.

pros: Room for creativity, adequate PI funding, positive encouragement and support for NIH F32 award applications.
cons: Reimbursement structure and HR paperwork is a complete mess. International Post Doc candidates, beware to complete your visa obligations well ahead of time- the international office on campus that deals with your paperwork is known to be very incompetent. Overall Cons- support, clerical, and base-level admin staff is underpaid for the job obligations required of them.

review_title: Great experience and exceptional pay, depending on position
job_title: Teaching and Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: As a teaching assistant, I was working with the top individuals in the field of study, working with students who cared and actively engaged in the material, and was paid $1,000/mo + $12.50/hr for research, which is much more than most other institutions and exceptional for the relatively low # of hours needed on the TA side of things.
cons: Administration is a bit out of touch at times. It can be a very 'political' environment and hierarchy depending on department.

review_title: Admissions Office - Great people Great environment.
pros: The Director of admissions is a genius and wonderful mentor. Anyone looking for some experience in the field of education should definitely look at the UChicago Admissions.
cons: Lack of formal structure in the operations side. They embrace the UChicago stereotype of wacky in the tour side which is a shame. There are a lot of great people that would make great tour guides.

review_title: It's an interesting place to work, things can be a little slow though
pros: If you find yourself the right supervisor, you can have a lot of fun.
cons: Public transit to Hyde Park is a nightmare. Benefits aren't great.

job_title: Psychology Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: It's a really great way to gain experience while you are in school or grad school and trying to learn what you want to pursue as a career.
cons: There tend to not be benefits and the pay is low, but hey it's a student job. So that's pretty much exactly what you expect out of it.

review_title: If you're ok with following the status quo and kiss up to management you'll do fine.
pros: All things considered, the benefits package is spectacular
cons: It wasn't a place that welcomed change and innovation. New ideas were constantly rejected and I never felt like I could really contribute to my team. Promotions were solely based on how much management liked you, not merit, which became incredibly frustrating. Management also isn't the best at fostering professional development. I couldn't grow the way I wanted to grow here.

review_title: It was a wonderful place to work for and in an absolutely beautiful atmosphere.
job_title: Executive Administrator II in Chicago, IL
pros: I love the beautiful campus.  The people are highly intelligent and have a lot of pride for the University.  The benefits are far above other places in Chicago.
cons: The biggest challenge was learning the structure of the University and fighting the "Chicago way".  They are very unreceptive to new ways of doing things.

pros: Other than the fact that my drive has been in half (Close to home).. That's it!  I can't think of any real Pro's for this organization. Please Note: I am referring to the University and not the Hospital.
cons: Depending on your department you will get Low Salary, No Perks, No appreciation, Worked to the bone.  Take it and be happy or hit the bricks mentality.

pros: Amazing job! I worked in a population genetics focussed research lab in the dept of human genetics. I published 5 papers in a single year, two with first author focus. I enjoyed collaborating with graduate students and postdocs, and implementing software pipelines for others, or the ones I conceived myself for the few first author projects
cons: Had no work-life balance. Mostly worked all the time. But the pay was great. I also loved doing research, so definitely enjoyed the publications coming through.

review_title: Overall I have been happy here, but I also am doing what I love; with any job there are things which need improvement.
pros: It is a very prestigious institution where interesting things happen on a regular basis. Overall I enjoy the people I work with.
cons: The pay doesn't seem scaled appropriately to the level of work we are expected and required to do.

pros: The University of Chicago has many top-tier researchers who are passionate about their fields. As a postdoc, it's a good place to concentrate on research and get good work done.
cons: My departmental administration is great, but the university administration doesn't seem to have much respect for postdocs. Postdoc benefits, for example, are done through a third-party contractor, and are not the same as any other university employees. It took them more than two months to start my health insurance when I started working here.

pros: Really smart colleagues among the staff, who understand the institution very well. And, excellent benefits and options for health insurance, child care savings, retirement savings..
cons: It's somewhat hierarchical, but it doesn't want to appear to be that way, so it can be tough to navigate, particularly if you have any interaction with faculty as part of your work.

pros: My department respects me a person and as an employee.  They respect my time and the fact that we have lives outside of work.
cons: I work in a high pressure environment with big deadlines. Pay raises are small but my job is flexible so that is a good trade. My commute from the other side of the city is tough.

review_title: U of C, IT Services - good
pros: ability to make a difference and give feedback, flexible work hours, work from home policy, annual reviews and several recognition programs, open positions e-mailed to all staff but the advancement process is competitive, good team atmosphere with people in my group
cons: would like better training plans and clearer advancement paths, work-life balance, long commute from west suburbs, parking, Lab School benefit can be tough to get for middle school kids

review_title: Don;t even apply to the Booth School!
pros: Based on my experience as a Booth School Staff member...NONE!
cons: Too many cons to list but just don't even bother to apply for jobs at the Booth School of Business! The leadership should be ashamed of how they treat their professional staff. The Booth School is a disgrace for the University of Chicago and the leadership should be removed so better management of the school could make this a better place to work!

job_title: Cloud Computing Software Engineer in Lemont, IL
pros: Solid, stable HR policies. Flexible telecommuting.
cons:
Bear in mind at a gigantic institution like this, 99% of the day-to-day is your group. Additionally, if, as in my case, it is funded independently through grants, 100% of non-HR-management things (insurance, payroll system, policies) are literally completely unglued from the greater organization.

Director of my group was extremely slow at hiring people, devoting practically no time to it. Would bemoan "we have all these grants and not enough people to work on them.

pros: Work with a lot of extremely talented and humble people. - Constant learning of useful engineering topics. - Freedom & flexibility. - Huge opportunities to work on what you like and propose ideas. - Perks. Everywhere.
cons: Great office, full of space and awesome furniture. Management take special care on the people that's part of the company. You won't be a number, everyone's opinion is considered, and there's no verticality at all.

pros: Insurance is not unreasonably priced for what you get (dental, vision, etc.). Working hours can also be reasonable depending upon who you work for. Access to services like UchicagoGrad for resources on job searching is nice.
cons: Unless you pay a higher upfront cost, accessing healthcare close to the university is difficult. Because you don't pay the student life fee, you technically don't have access to many departmental activities such as "town hall meetings." If you work in a lab, the safety culture could be better.

pros: Office culture is fun and relaxed. There are lots of opportunities and perks when working for Career Advancement as a student. The greatest of these is access to the Keurig machine, which is phenomenal for student employees. Ability to work from home is occasionally awarded to superb interns.
cons: Bureaucracy is sometimes difficult and frustrating to navigate. The coffee machine sometimes is out of coffee. Both of these things are terrible cons.

pros: The best reasons to work here are the caliber of students that you work with. They are highly intelligent and curious.
cons: It is a toxic, sexist environment where the adminstration treats you like garbage. The benefits suck, many of your coworkers don't care about students and there is a lot of mediocrity, the commute sucks. This was the worst job I have ever had, and after this experience I will  never work at a university again.

review_title: Varies from department to department, but I have found great opportunity for growth
pros: Great benefits, academic environment and colleagues, quality people, opportunities for promotion or transition between departments since many managers value internal promotion
cons: Not many to count, but like most jobs, if you have a bad manager you are going to have a bad experience. Mostly, very great people

pros: The budget for experiments better than last lab. I am able to buy things which I was not able to purchase before to help with projects but still not a crazy large budget. The manager is hands off and does not argue often. He seems interested in getting work done instead of distracted all the time. Decent line of communication.
cons: Unusually low salary. University of chicago is well known for paying poorly. The salary is lower than any technician salary at Northwestern and their has been no cost of living increases.   Poor project management, things are disorganized. The position is extremely isolating, only about a quarter of the staff speaks english regularly.

job_title: Associate Director, Development and Alumni Relations in Chicago, IL
pros: Intellectually stimulating environment.  Great alumni population to work with.  Medical benefits were good.
cons: Horrible match for low to mid-level staff for the 403(b) plan, particularly compared to other universities in the Chicago area.  Very intense environment to work in, particularly in fundraising with expectations that were too high and not enough support.  Great university, but one that does not promote a healthy work-life balance for its staff.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Intellectual community, neighborhood oriented, lots of opportunities, congenial co-workers, beautiful campus, ability to move to different positions on campus, great students
cons: low pay, the neighborhood can be dicey, transportation options to campus are limited--depending on where you live, very academic and can be a little boring

review_title: excellent experience in learning your field. It is also very easy to network and get to know people in your office.
pros: I love the hours, loved my colleagues. I got a change early on to test out my skills and to figure out exactly where I fit in the company.
cons: The pay is the worst. It takes about 3 years to really see an increase in your pay. That was something I was expecting. Also, it not that easy to move up the chain.

pros: Coworkers are good people and the culture is one where people are able to get invested in a problem and dedicate time to fix it/improve it.
cons: The location is a bit of a drag.  It isn't really that easy to access via public transportation and the area is pretty dangerous if you go a few blocks off campus.

review_title: Good Place to Work, Very Idealistic
pros: Interesting work and colleagues, great benefits. Wonderful to work with departments across campus on a common goal. I really felt like I was making a difference in the world when working here.
cons: Average to low salaries for positions (as with many non-profits); made it hard to find housing in Hyde Park. At times university bureaucracy and politics got in the way of progress. Financial and IT departments often difficult to navigate in an effective way.

pros: Overall good working culture and great faculty to work with. I highly recommend working here given that you won't find a smarter group of people.
cons: Can be a bit rough getting your pay set up. I wasn't told I would need my passport for my i9 until the day of processing so the onboarding process was rough.

review_title: Rewarding work, poor administration, employees not valued
job_title: Associate Director, Development and Alumni Relations in Chicago, IL
pros: The students and alumni are very energetic and working with them is rewarding. Prestigious university that looks great on a resume.
cons: Very limited path to promotion, don't value their employees; constant leadership changes means no environmental consistency and ever changing priorities; they work you to death, then dispose of you when you get burnt out

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Chicago, IL
pros: You are getting paid to go to school and get another degree!
cons: Your experience really depends on the professor you choose to work with. Many are known to not be nice and demand more than is possible and are never available to help or discuss. They don’t have your best interest at heart. No vision or dental insurance. Location of university is not the safest.

pros: The hours are good, and pay is reasonable.  Overtime is allowed and unrestricted.  The work is interesting and, if you are in a good lab, the people are great to work with.  Once you're in a department, they are willing to work to keep you even if you have to switch labs because of changes in funding.
cons: In the wrong lab, no matter how interesting the work, your day-to-day life can be terrible.  Choose your lab carefully.

pros: The students at the University of Chicago are wonderful.  It is always a pleasure to be able to teach intellectually curious and motivated students.
cons: Uchicago management really could care less about staff.  Lecturers remain grossly under compensated for their services, and this won't change without some kind of pressure on the administration.

pros: Good benefits, beautiful campus, lots of interesting people.  Lots of money to build the newest hardware.  Campus food is pretty good.
cons: If you leave the campus area, it can be very scary near by especially at night.  Many students get mugged each year.  As a university if you don't have a PHD your options at career growth are very limited.

review_title: Great environment to grow and be challenged
pros: You are surrounded by some of the best academics in the world and have access to a large number of seminars. You are pushed to work a lot, but there is definitely attention to keep a healthy life-work balance. The projects I'm working on are interesting and I'm given some autonomy.
cons: There are many Research Professionals, so it is hard to emerge. It is not possible to work from remote (if not on rare occasions).

review_title: A University between Business and Academia
job_title: Research Professional Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: University of Chicago is a prestigious University, and well respected in the industry. The work hours are very flexible, and the academic environment is excellent.
cons: This is a very competitive university. Emphasis lies on performance, rather than novel academic discoveries. The recent cost cutbacks are frustrating, and management makes decisions based on numbers rather than social impact.

pros:
This review is for the Circulation Department at Regenstein Library
Generous salary
Flexibility in scheduling
Understanding and friendly management
Professional but relaxed environment
cons: Not really a resume booster, but it is a great way to make money while still having plenty of time to be a full-time student.

pros: As a part-time student worker, I had great flexibility of hours and opportunities to take on projects of my choosing. They're very willing to give you time for personal reasons and for classes, while also letting you pursue things you want to work on.
cons: No real cons for a student worker -- the work-life balance was good, as was compensation at $12 per hour. However, there's no real way to move up or join after graduation.

pros: A great environment where good work where is prized and collaboration is highly encouraged. The administrative and technical support personnel are, as a rule, exemplary, and the pay is above market.
cons: A high focus on advertising and selling science distracts from research. Very little supervisor investment in continued education or job placement kills prospects after these positions.

pros: The Professors at UChicago at not just the teachers of UChicago students, but rather, they are teachers of the world. These are the world experts in what they do and their research projects are extremely interesting and relevant. RA work was very location flexible and my boss was a great mentor. I greatly improved my skills in R and Python and learned a lot about what it takes to be a successful researcher.
cons: I cannot think of any cons.

review_title: It's a big school, I can only judge one department
job_title: Program Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, lots of options. There is definitely a lot of support, you can talk your way into auditing classes for free if you show an interest.
cons: Professors are god, everyone else lives to serve them. People can be snobby about what sort of degrees you have.

review_title: Great place to learn from top-notch researchers
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Very friendly faculty and staff, great opportunity to learn numerous techniques, great opportunity to meet many new people and work with many different teams, benefits are good
cons: pay could be better, extremely faced paced, often feels like there is minimal room for error, disagreements between faculty members can feel a bit stifling sometimes, growth or improvement is not only based on personal performance but often feels based on external circumstances that cannot be controlled

pros: Chicago Booth is a collaborate, innovative environment that is always looking to improve and seek new ideas. They are committed to providing professional development for their staff.
cons: Chicago Booth is slow to promote it's employees. Often is takes at least 3 years to obtain a promotion unless you are changing roles from office to office.

review_title: It's a bureaucracy, but they take care of their people.
pros: stable and perhaps growing departments once this whole recession thing is finished with. the checks come on time thanks to the massive payroll department.
cons: it is chicago, and chicago is cold. that is all i can say about that for the moment. i left chicago.

review_title: UoC is a very good place to work learn and develop
pros:
As a researcher in UoC you can work with some of the best scientist in the country. Academy life are great: Interesting, rewarding and extremely good work life balance.
Basically, you are free to do whatever is in your interest and you get paid for it!
cons:
You must be self motivated. No one will tell you what to do.
Also compensation is less then in corporates.

pros: Many opportunities for growth internationally for several units on campus. The University's strong brand opens many doors globally.
cons: Highly decentralized campus makes processes cumbersome.  Some units are highly dysfunctional. Staff are not necessarily highly valued. Faculty are everything.  Culture is provincial somehow, and there are pockets of highly uncollegial units and teams. Management in general is poor on people skills.

pros: Excellent resources and cutting edge research. Profs and peers are leaders in their fields, and facilities have improved with all the construction of new research buildings.
cons: University is divided into many scientific committees, this creates little kingdoms for profs to rule over. Some are effective administrators, some are quite poor.

pros: Great career experience.  Working with UofC will definitely lead to higher career opportunities.  So many wonderful prop,e that I am honored to have enjoyed working with and sharing life together.
cons: Not a lot of oversight of "those in charge."

pros: Meet lots of people and have fun with coworkers. The patrons are nice and not demanding. There is a union here though and first pick is theirs.
cons: Not much room for moving up. Union jobs arent necessarily given to all who deserve it because they get first pick.

pros: Working here has been an absolute joy and I could not have been happier with my choice to pursue this undertaking at an institution that prides itself on being a haven for life of the mind.
cons: Despite what some may say, the self deprecating attitudes of the general undergraduate student population is not representative of the true culture that would thrive in this type of community. People are genuine, work hard, and strive to find meaning.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Department has wonderful core facilities (NMR, mass spectrometry, etc). Faculty in the department are among top in the research world, most professors are young, ambitious and very productive. Overall research climate is very positive
cons: Since there is no engineering department in UChicago, most of the common employers who are interested in chemists ignore the university, that makes it harder to find an industry position. Recruiting events are extremely rare and usually not very productive

review_title: Program Manager for a $$ research program
pros:
- flexible working hours
- work with some of the smartest economists in the world
- work on cutting edge policy issues
- entrepreneurial role
cons:
- university is not an exciting workplace
- work pace is unpredictable
- unstructured growth path and learning environment
- not enough $ paid

pros: The Urban Education Institute is at the cutting edge of education research. It was a pleasure to work there and utilize the resources of the university to solve fascinating questions.
cons: The internship is a typical research assistant job. You will work in data cleaning and spend a lot of time coding or creating presentations.

pros: You get great access to University of Chicago. You get many vacation, personal and holidays off.
cons: Union. They do not give much of T.A. for schools other than UChicago. The pay raise is so insignificant.

pros:
As far as teaching goes, they offered a great salary. I was surrounded by qualified teachers. The majority worked very hard. 
-
cons: The directors attempt to be hands on, but are not coordinated to do so. They commonly did not preview lesson plans and observed during the wrong times. There was little to no autonomy in teaching and their methods were not always best practice. The director could never be found. The management of the school needed improvement.

pros: Lots of resources and opportunities for students to grow, great mentors, a wonderful place to work for anyone interested in pursuing a PhD
cons: Logistical nightmare - took forever to get employee access as a student from another university and actually delayed my pay

review_title: Changing IT Department Culture Generates Much Uncertainty
pros:
Opportunity to work with cutting edge technology
Highly competent, talented, goal-oriented, and friendly staff
Flexible working environment--can work from home
cons:
New senior IT management that is changing the culture
Work environment was highly collaborative--now appears to be "edict from above"
A lot of uncertainty about the future directions of the IT organization

pros: Good benefits, gorgeous campus, great colleagues.
cons: The students are overly entitled. The University doesn't value student affairs, and even within the unit there is a lack of resources. There is an expectation that you'll work 50/60 hours a week for pay that is much lower than average, especially in student affairs.

review_title: The Urban Education Institute is beyond awful.
pros: There are none. I guess if I had to say something it would be that they have decent benefits.
cons:
If you don't agree with your boss, you're in for trouble
They will never fire you but I have heard them talk about making the environment bad enough to make people quit (constructive discharge)
Very much a shut-up and do your work mentality
Staff do not bother showing up for meetings on time 
Management has no real world experience 
Management is untrustworthy
They waste grant money left and right

pros: The Campus is welcoming, a lot of innovative, scientific contributions are made from the world class scientists, & the location is easily accessible.
cons: University processes, systems, and practices  are cumbersome and, in most cases, outdated making it difficult to get things done in a timely & efficient manner

pros: U of C is a solid institution with great benefits for full time employees. Working in an academic research lab while also living in Hyde Park gives one a very flexible schedule and has proven to be a fairly relaxed working environment.
cons: If one does not live close to the University the commute into the city is terrible. And while benefits and work schedule are great overall pay is not that high.

review_title: Wonderful experience at University of Chicago
pros: University of Chicago is a very famous university. And Chicago city is very beautiful and a wonderful place to live in.
cons: The neighborhood, hyde park, is not a safe place, I would not recommend you walk alone in the middle of night.

pros: It's a vibrant community where there's always a lot of interesting events going on. The professional standards in my area (which is external-facing) are very high. Generally, the pace of work is challenging enough to be interesting, but also allows a good work/life balance (i.e. generally not a lot of overtime).
cons: It can be hard to get recognized and promoted, particularly if you've worked there a long time and/or you are part-time.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Chicago, IL
pros: It very depends what kind of course you TA for. It could be a lot of work like core PhD courses or could be very light work such as elective undergrad courses.
cons: They pay is terrible. Although if you find a course which does not take much time might not be that bad hourly

pros: The school has first-class teaching and research faculty as well as a thriving student body. The environment is competitive and the competitions are rewarding.
cons: The location of the school may not be the most ideal among universities with the same reputation in terms of weather, community, and safety.

review_title: A great place to get your bearings and learn on the job
pros: Huge medical system with large variety of specialties, average pay for the Chicago area. Good health insurance.
cons: Large bureaucratic system is slow to react to employees leaving. Feels like management does not trust the team. Feeling lack of strong leadership during the pandemic.

job_title: Research Lab Manager in Chicago, IL
pros:
Great reputation as everyone recognizes the name
Lots of opportunities in various divisions of the University
Great campus and well maintained buildings
cons:
Bad location as the neighborhood is not safe
Career growth is very poor as not much in terms of hierarchies

pros: Good name recognition. The campus itself is very pretty with a traditional college feel. Being close to a major metropolitan area nice.
cons: The faculty can be a bit stuffy. Most of the buildings are out of date. The area surrounding the university is not very safe.

review_title: not very bad, but the career service is not very good.
pros: university of chicago is a very very good university. it has a very high reputation with great professors, but the career service is not very good.
cons: the campus is pretty. the professors at university of chicago are good.

review_title: Being an RA really pays off
job_title: Assistant Resident Head in Chicago, IL
pros: Great benefits, residents love you. The Housing System as a whole is well set up so that each House is its own autonomous unit, so you're responsible for your residents only most of the time. Houses are really close-knit.
cons: It can be a lot to manage on top of schoolwork. Emergencies can happen at any time, and you have to be available.

review_title: Great People, very professional, easy to communicate
job_title: Research Professional Associate in Chicago, IL
pros:
Benefits
Compensation
Ability to move up
Leadership possibilities
Multicultural
Wonderful people
Safe work environment
Once hired nice job security
Considered non profit for student loan repayment
cons:
Location safe, but technically south side
In order to move up you really have to stand out, but very possible if you're hard working
Easy to conform, so many do and then complain about not moving up

pros: Great Benefits and Pay, Union Worker, Open Campus lunch, exposure to other job opportunities & opportunity to progress in my academic career while working for them.Every day is different from the one prior. The staff and co-workers are very cooperative and eager to help in whatever way possible
cons: Long work hours but I did not find any aspect of this assignment, or the people to be problematic.

pros: Great research is being done here, and collaborations are common and encouraged.  It has been a good opportunity to be productive in my postdoc.
cons: The administration of the Biological Science Division is cumbersome, with lots of confusion in the HR department about how to handle postdoc benefits.

review_title: A prestigious university with high-quality faculty, staff, and students
pros: Since it is a large organization, there are many opportunities for growth, mentorship, and professional networking. Excellence is a standard, not a goal.
cons: Large organizations can also foster layers of inefficient bureaucracy. This University reorganizes often but teams, departments, and divisions don't always collaborate as well as they could.

review_title: Meaningful and Inspiring Place to Work
job_title: Vulnerability and Compliance Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Inspiring, intelligence in high concentration, flexibility, excellence, meaningful work.  Service to community, to the world of medicine and science and research.  Beautiful and historic neighborhood and campus.
cons: It can be very challenging working among so many brilliant type A personalities.  This work can be very demanding but very enjoyable and rewarding at the same time.

pros: Excellent place to complete undergrad, whether you want pre-professional training or a run-through of the rigors of graduate school.
cons: Not in a particularly nice area. Hyde Park has its perks, but it takes a good forty minutes by public transit to reach any of the other interesting neighborhoods in Chicago.

review_title: The University of Chicago Law School: Where Innovation Comes to Die
pros:
- Great benefits (unless you're pregnant)
- Fans of the 1980's can enjoy an immersive experience
- You will never take your work home with you
cons:
- Outdated attitudes and approaches to work
- Reluctance to try anything new
- No upward mobility

review_title: Enrollment & Student Advancement (ESA) - Career Advancement Office
pros:
-Pay 
-Benefits
-Campus resources
-Opportunity for some travel
-Industry exposure
cons:
-Lack of employee development
-Inadequate training 
-Senior Leadership
-Lack of transparency
-Lack in a flexible work schedule
-High turnover in department
-Inconsistent work space

review_title: Campus and Student Life - Good Working Culture
pros: Good benefits and reasonable work-life balance, if you want it. Most of the people I work with are friendly and warm.
cons: Change takes forever to happen. Culture can be extremely bureaucratic and processes much slower than they need to be.

pros: A great group of people to work with. Fast-paced with plenty of new skills to learn. The position gives a broad scope of the ARD organization as a whole.
cons: A bit of a large organization so some people may feel less than useful at the University.

review_title: My time spent working at the school was unremarkable.
pros: Beautiful campus with lots of history. Nice energy around students in a critically acclaimed institution. Good name recognition for your resume.
cons: The pay in higher ed is generally lower than in consumer companies. Not all of your colleagues and supervisors are of high quality, perhaps due to the lower pay. Parking is a pain.
